ResourceHeader.Description: Hinode is a Japanese spacecraft making high resolution observations of the sun at optical, EUV and X-ray wavelengths. Scientific foci include solar magnetic fields and coronal heating. Hinode was launched on September 22, 2006 (UT) into a low altitude, sun-synchronous orbit. Its pre-launch name was Solar-B.

ResourceHeader.Description: The Hinode EUV Imaging Spectrometer simultaneously measures in the 170-210 and 250-290 Angstrom ranges using two large back-illuminated CCDs. EIS utilizes an off-axis parabolic primary and a toroidal diffraction grating in a normal-incidence optical layout.

ResourceHeader.Description: The Solar Optical telescope on Hinode consists of a main 50cm aperture telescope and a CCD-based focal plane package. SOT is optimized for accurate measurement of the vector magnetic field in the photosphere and the dynamics of both the photosphere and chromosphere associated with the magnetic fields. SOT obtains diffraction-limited images (0.2-0.3") in the 388-668 nm range. Pointing stability is maintained at < 0.09" in 3 sigma.

ResourceHeader.Description: The Hinode X-Ray Telescope (XRT) is a high resolution grazing incidence telescope consisting of X-ray and visible light optics, focal plane mechanisms (filters and shutter) and a 2k x 2k CCD camera. It operates over a 2 - 200 Angstrom bandwidth.
